data.title: Opening terminal gives "Cannot set property 'innerHTML' of undefined"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0-insider (24e811)
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open integrated terminal
2. Type e.g. 'dir' and press enter
3. Toggle/close integrated terminal
4. Toggle/open integrated terminal

Expected: Terminal opens
Actual: Error: Cannot set property 'innerHTML' of undefined

Problem exists both with cmd.exe as terminal, and with `"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "\\Program Files\\Git\\Bin\\bash.exe"`

data.title: Go To Definition opens first match
data.body:
Is this the desired behaviour when having multiple matches? I mean, you still have to confirm with Esc or Enter to close the preview so I argue that it should behave just like Peek Definition instead and not open the first match.

![go_to_definition_open](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1297882/15851950/813949b6-2c9f-11e6-886c-9992b4cb2652.gif)

The downside of opening the first match is that with the default `"explorer.autoReveal": true`, you potentially expand a lot of folders permanently which clutters the tree view.

1.2.0-insider
Win10

data.title: Search in all files, including files and folders excluded through settings

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is a feature request.

I'd like to see an option under the search menu, to search in all files and folders, ignoring the configured exclusions. Very often I find myself needing to find a piece of code in my `node_modules` or the generated output for debugging reasons. So, it would be nice to be able to include globally excluded folders without having to remove the exclusions.

I'd be happy to work on a PR if someone could point me in the right direction to the source files involved.

data.title: Default settings contains warnings for Integrated terminal configuration options
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open User settings 
2. Open the problems view
3. Warnings are generated for integrated terminal configuration options

Expected: There should not be any warnings generated from the settings file

![warnings from user settings](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10746682/15897556/44c2d12c-2d95-11e6-9c39-9a402e0dfa6e.png)

As a result on clicking these warnings an error is shown
![error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10746682/15850971/22f3239e-2c9b-11e6-8927-32ecb4722854.PNG)

First of all no warnings/errors are expected from default settings file.

Second, If there are, its correct that Problems view is showing them

Third, I am not sure if it is expected to show the above error on opening the above file, especially if these default settings files are generated and not-editable - @bpasero your input would be helpful here

data.title: Broken TAB spacing in less after variables
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Win 10 x64 Pro (CZ) - current "non-insider" build

Steps to Reproduce:
1. `@grid_sm_end:767px;` when i want to align variables in config and press TAB after :
2. it will do this `@grid_sm_end::;767px;` pressing tab again will just add more: `@grid_sm_end:::::;767px;`

i had problems with this before, when it would completely rewrite variable name with something else

**Workaround:** use space after : then press TAB

---

im using TABs, becouse i know people around world preffer different spacing, like 2 spaces or even 8. In code 2 tabs can look like 2 spaces or 4 spaces for me.. it just depends on your editor settings. I hate spaces, it forces people to use someone elses spacing... TAB can be as wide as you want with still having same code in background <-- just in case someone gonna try respond "use spaces" (:

data.title: Cannot launch debug target (spawn node ENOENT).
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0 (1.2.0)
- OS Version: MacOS 10.11.4 (15E65)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create launch.json profile
   f.e.
   {
     "name": "Launch",
     "type": "node",
     "request": "launch",
     "program": "${workspaceRoot}/a.js",
     "stopOnEntry": false,
     "args": [],
     "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
     "preLaunchTask": null,
     "runtimeExecutable": null,
     "runtimeArgs": [
       "--nolazy"
     ],
     "env": {
       "NODE_ENV": "development"
     },
     "externalConsole": false,
     "sourceMaps": false,
     "outDir": null
   },
2. Create a.js in a root of a project
3. Run Debug
4. It throws an error "Cannot launch debug target (spawn node ENOENT)."

data.title: Terminal actions need cleanup
data.body:
I find it hard to figure out what to do when typing `>terminal` in the command prompt:

![screen shot 2016-06-07 at 09 23 00](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/15849183/81835b0e-2c91-11e6-8434-87cacac8afa3.png)

Maybe something more like this?
- Open System Terminal
- Open Integrated Terminal
- Focus Integrated Terminal

Or, with the category sections:
- Terminal: Open System Terminal
- Terminal: Open Integrated Terminal
- Terminal: Focus Integrated Terminal

data.title: Set locale variables automatically for the integrated terminal
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.2.0 - OS Version: OSX 10.11.5 Steps to Reproduce: 1. I use ZSH for shell. 2. Open Integrated Terminal and run `locale`. 3. Locale is not set properly. Here is my result: ``` LANG= LC_COLLATE="C" LC_CTYPE="C" LC_MESSAGES="C" LC_MONETARY="C" LC_NUMERIC="C" LC_TIME="C" LC_ALL= ``` Expected: An optional similar to the default Terminal app in OSX. It makes sense to have it ON by default. Option from Terminal settings: Workaround: Add the following to your profile (`~/.zhrc` for ZSH): ``` export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8 export LANG=en_US.UTF-8 ```

data.title: [CSS] Add specificity to selector preview?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Currently when one hovers over a selector in a CSS file it gives a preview of what it selects. This is useful for beginners or if you just forget what a particular selector does.

What would make this even more useful is to also include the specificity of the selector in the preview popup. Many beginners/intermediate don't understand specificity, which is why you often see super specific selectors all over. Even for experts, it would be quicker than calculating yourself for longer selectors.

Example:

```
-----------------------------
<select>

<option :checked>
Specificity: 0,1,2
-----------------------------
select option:checked
```

Note: I used how CSS2.1 defines specificity. CSS3 Selectors defines it as 012, which I think is confusing as it makes it look like if there were 10 classes or pseudo classes it would be 102 rather than 0102. CSS 4 Selectors shows it as a=0 b=1 c=2.

Code already exists to calculate specificity in JS if you want to add using 3rd party code https://github.com/keeganstreet/specificity

data.title: API request : Allow the language mode to provide `indent` information
data.body:
CodeMirror modes can provide an `indent` function that is called with the `state` object for the line so that one can use it to provide a true formatted indent for a line. 

I used this in alm here : https://github.com/alm-tools/alm/blob/c7d31e48864a96379fabe27d1bb507ccce3e9319/src/app/codemirror/mode/typescriptMode.ts#L206-L214

As you can see it allowed me to offload to the TypeScript language service I have running on the client (in the form of the classifier cache). 

It would be great if `onEnterRules?: IOnEnterRegExpRules[];` could also take a function (`(state:IState, textAfter:string)`).

data.title: Markdown syntax highlighing confused by backslashes and quotes

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Open the attached file [markdown.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/301913/markdown.txt) in VSCode.
2.  Enable word wrap to be able to view the entire paragraph.
3.  Rename the file to have the '.md' extension identifying it as Markdown
4.   Observe syntax coloring of the markdown text.   The entire sentence starting with the phrase "One set of encoded values" is inappropriately colored blue because the syntax highlighting code in VSCode is confused by the example.   

Note: results from processing this markdown using grunt-markdown results in HTML producing the desired effect, the flaw seems to be in the markdown highlighting logic.

data.title: `Error: end of central directory record signature not found` on Linux Travis tests
data.body:
I'm seeing Travis failures for `vscode-go` with this error, but only on Linux, not OS/X.  This is seen building the current master branch of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go.  

It looks like a different issue than #2384 though that led to the same error message.

```
$ npm test --silent
### VS Code Extension Test Run ###
Current working directory: /home/travis/gopath/src/github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go
Downloading VS Code into "/home/travis/gopath/src/github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/.vscode-test" from: https://vscode-update.azurewebsites.net/1.2.0/linux-x64/stable
stream.js:94
      throw er; // Unhandled stream error in pipe.
            ^
Error: end of central directory record signature not found
    at /home/travis/gopath/src/github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/node_modules/vscode/node_modules/gulp-vinyl-zip/node_modules/yauzl/index.js:167:14
    at /home/travis/gopath/src/github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/node_modules/vscode/node_modules/gulp-vinyl-zip/node_modules/yauzl/index.js:475:5
    at Object._onImmediate (/home/travis/gopath/src/github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/node_modules/vscode/node_modules/gulp-vinyl-zip/node_modules/yauzl/node_modules/fd-slicer/index.js:200:5)
    at processImmediate [as _immediateCallback] (timers.js:354:15)
The command "npm test --silent" exited with 1.
```

data.title: Find all references in CSS cuts off before hyphen in property name
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  Version 1.2.0 (1.2.0)
- OS Version:
  OS X 10.lostCount

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Right click on a CSS property value
2. Find all occurrences 

Expected:

See all of the property name as even the longest CSS properties are not that long

Actual:

It seems in most cases it trims before the last hyphen, but sometimes it keeps a little more. 

This is probably a design decision (to keep the values aligned?) but I thought I'd file a bug as the property  a value is defined on is often relevant, and many different properties end with the same last word (background-color, color, boder-left-color; background-image, border-image, etc.), and with CSS properties not being super long, there is often room to fit the full property. In the screenshot it even includes the comment.

![screen shot 2016-06-06 at 9 24 16 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/465069/15846068/4ab0f270-2c2e-11e6-98ff-c638b53c36cd.png)

data.title: Support terminal theme on colors 16-255
Git bash shell was opened in a standalone window instead of integrated on Windows
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.10240]

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add the following to settings.json

``` json
    // The path of the shell that the terminal uses on Windows.
    "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Program Files\\Git\\git-bash.exe"
```
1. Close and re-open VSCode (so that the new settings.json would take effect).
2. Choose `View` -> `Toggle Integrated Terminal` from menu.

In this case, the "TERMINAL" panel shows up but remains in blank, and the git bash shell was opened as a standalone window instead of integrated. Checkout the snapshot below:

![integrated shell](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6123222/15844934/fae4fa3e-2ca0-11e6-804b-f080b7b9d14b.PNG)

data.title: Selections in terminal should invert colors like in bash
data.body: Made a request to xterm https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/75, it will be too tedious to do without scripting the CSS on our side though unless they go back to a JS API for theming.

data.title: disconnectRequest never called
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Generated project based on mock debug adapter
2. Added disconnectRequest implementation to class derived from DebugSession
3. Start the debugger (in server or local mode) then stop with the stop button.
   Result: disconnectRequest is not called
   Expected: disconnectRequest called
